      3b
      On the Mechanism of Hydrogen Storage in a Metal-Organic Framework Material
      Belof, Jonathan L.; Stern, Abraham C.; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Space, Brian
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (49), 15202-15210CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Monte Carlo simulations were performed to model H sorption in a metal-org. framework material (MOF) that exhibits large mol. H uptake capacity. The MOF is remarkable because at 78 K and 1.0 atm it sorbs H at a d. near that of liq. H (at 20 K and 1.0 atm) when considering H2 d. in the pores. Unlike most other MOFs that have been studied for H storage, it has an ionic framework and many small channels. The simulations demonstrate that it is both of these phys. characteristics that lead to strong H interactions in the MOF and ultimately large H uptake. Microscopically, H interacts with the MOF via 3 principle attractive potential energy contributions: Van der Waals, charge-quadrupole and induction. Previous simulations of H storage in MOFs and other materials have not focused on the role of polarization effects, but they are demonstrated here to be the dominant contribution to H physisorption. Indeed, polarization interactions in the MOF lead to 2 distinct populations of dipolar H that are identified from the simulations and that should be evident in Raman spectra. Since polarization interactions are enhanced by the presence of a charged framework with narrow pores, MOFs are excellent H storage candidates.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXht1yrtbfK&md5=ff9450f53d18424c86347665dc307c2e
      (c) Chen, B., Ma, S., Zapata, F., Lobkovsky, E. B., and Yang, J. Inorg. Chem. 2006, 45, 5718
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3c
      Hydrogen Adsorption in an Interpenetrated Dynamic Metal-Organic Framework
      Chen, Banglin; Ma, Shengqian; Zapata, Fatima; Lobkovsky, Emil B.; Yang, Jun
      Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (15), 5718-5720CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      A metal-org. framework Zn(NDC)(4,4'-Bpe)0.5·xG [NDC = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate; 4,4'-Bpe = 4,4'-trans-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene; G = guest mols.] has been synthesized, structurally characterized, and rationalized to be a two-interpenetrated elongated primitive cubic net. Powder X-ray diffraction and adsorption studies reveal the dynamic feature of the framework, which can take up hydrogen of about 2.0 wt % at 77 K and 40 bar and 0.3 wt % at 298 K and 65 bar.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XmtVygs78%253D&md5=b197758becbf44473a4c5f597817166f
      (d) Eddaoudi, M., Li, H., and Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2000, 122, 1391
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3d
      Highly porous and stable metal-organic frameworks. Structure design and sorption properties
      Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Li, Hailian; Yaghi, O. M.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2000), 122 (7), 1391-1397CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Gas sorption isotherm measurements performed on the evacuated derivs. of 4 porous metal-org. frameworks (MOF-n), Zn(BDC).(DMF)(H2O) (DMF = N,N'-dimethylformamide, BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) (MOF-2), Zn3(BDC)3.6CH3OH (MOF-3), Zn2(BTC)NO3.(C2H5OH)5H2O (BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) (MOF-4), and Zn4O(BDC)3.(DMF)8C6H5Cl (MOF-5), reveal type I isotherms for n = 2, 3, and 5, which is evidence of microporous and accessible channels having high structural integrity and organization. Although gas sorption into MOF-4 was not obsd., careful examn. of its ethanol sorption isotherms at 22 and 32° point to the presence of coordinatively unsatd. Zn centers within its pores, which upon ethanol sorption undergo coordination transitions from 3- to 4-, 4- to 5-, and 5- to 6-coordination. MOF-n materials were produced by building the extended analogs of mol. metal carboxylate clusters, a strategy that has allowed the realization of the most porous and thermally stable framework yet reported: the evacuated form of MOF-5 is esp. stable in air at 300° and has a free pore vol. representing 55-60% of its crystal as detd. by gas sorption and single-crystal diffraction studies.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXotl2jsg%253D%253D&md5=bf52caa3fb6a6e160f205f938db8b3a7
      (e) Farha, O. K., Malliakas, C. D., Kanatzidis, M. G., and Hupp, J. T. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 132, 950
      [ACS Full Text ], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      (f) Luo, J., Xu, H., Liu, Y., Zhao, Y., Daemen, L. L., Brown, C., Timofeeva, T. V., Ma, S., and Zhou, H.-C. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2008, 130, 9626
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3f
      Hydrogen Adsorption in a Highly Stable Porous Rare-Earth Metal-Organic Framework: Sorption Properties and Neutron Diffraction Studies
      Luo, Junhua; Xu, Hongwu; Liu, Yun; Zhao, Yusheng; Daemen, Luke L.; Brown, Craig; Timofeeva, Tatiana V.; Ma, Shengqian; Zhou, Hong-Cai
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (30), 9626-9627CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A highly stable porous lanthanide metal-org. framework, Y(BTC)(H2O)·4.3H2O (BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate), with pore size of 5.8 Å has been constructed and investigated for hydrogen storage. Gas sorption measurements show that this porous metal-org. framework exhibits highly selective sorption behaviors of hydrogen over nitrogen gas mols. and can take up hydrogen of ∼2.1 wt.% at 77 K and 10 bar. Difference Fourier anal. of neutron powder diffraction data revealed four distinct D2 sites that are progressively filled within the nanoporous framework. Interestingly, the strongest adsorption sites identified are assocd. with the arom. org. linkers rather than the open metal sites, as occurred in previously reported metal-org. frameworks. Our results provide for the first time direct structural evidence demonstrating that optimal pore size (∼6 Å, twice the kinetic diam. of hydrogen) strengthens the interactions between H2 mols. and pore walls and increases the heat of adsorption, which thus allows for enhancing hydrogen adsorption from the interaction between hydrogen mols. with the pore walls rather than with the normally stronger adsorption sites (the open metal sites) within the framework. At high concn. H2 loadings (5.5 H2 mols. (3.7 wt.%) per Y(BTC) formula), H2 mols. form highly sym. novel nanoclusters with relatively short H2-H2 distances compared to solid H2. These observations are important and hold the key to optimizing this new class of rare metal-org. framework materials for practical hydrogen storage applications.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXot1ahsLY%253D&md5=cea045a6078dd9a155f4cac197b772f1
      (g) Ma, S., Sun, D., Ambrogio, M., Fillinger, J. A., Parkin, S., and Zhou, H.-C. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2007, 129, 1858
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3g
      Framework-Catenation Isomerism in Metal-Organic Frameworks and Its Impact on Hydrogen Uptake
      Ma, Shengqian; Sun, Daofeng; Ambrogio, Michael; Fillinger, Jacqueline A.; Parkin, Sean; Zhou, Hong-Cai
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (7), 1858-1859CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A strategy to control framework-catenation in metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) was presented; contributions to H uptake from interpenetration and unsatd. metal centers were resolved. Non-interpenetrated counterpart of Cu3(TATB)2(H2O)3, Cu6(H2O)6(TATB)4·DMA·12H2O (I; H3TATB = 4,4',4''-s-triazine-2,4,6-trityltribenzoic acid; DMA = dimethylacetamide), was prepd. by the reaction of Cu(NO3)2 with H3TATB in presence of oxalic acid. The crystal structure of I was detd. In I the dicopper tetracarboxylate paddle-wheel secondary building units are linked by TATB bridges and each secondary building unit connects 4 TATB ligands and each TATB binds 3 secondary building units. The uptake of H2 by I was compared with that of Cu3(TATB)2(H2O)3, the latter being reproduced by 2 identical interpenetrated nets of I.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXpsVWrtw%253D%253D&md5=74591e70169d3dddc34c4a258fdeb2d6
      (h) Mulfort, K. L. and Hupp, J. T. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2007, 129, 9604
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3h
      Chemical Reduction of Metal-Organic Framework Materials as a Method to Enhance Gas Uptake and Binding
      Mulfort, Karen L.; Hupp, Joseph T.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (31), 9604-9605CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A mixed-ligand metal-org. framework (MOF) of the formula Zn2(NDC)2(diPyNI) (NDC = 2,6-dicarboxylate, diPyNI = N,N'-di-(4-pyridyl)-1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetracarboxydiimide) has been chem. reduced in the solid state by lithium metal in DMF (DMF). Striking hysteresis in the N2 adsorption isotherm suggests dynamic framework behavior of the reduced material that is not obsd. in the neutral MOF. The reduced framework also exhibits significantly enhanced H2 uptake and isosteric heat of adsorption over the entire loading range. Notably, the striking increase in H2 uptake cannot be solely attributed to H2-Li+ interactions and is most likely augmented by increased ligand polarizability and framework displacement effects.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXnslGqt70%253D&md5=4974e45caa9b017fe5f7995311f8a132
      (i) Sava, D. F., Kravtsov, V. C., Eckert, J., Eubank, J. F., Nouar, F., and Eddaoudi, M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 10394
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3i
      Exceptional Stability and High Hydrogen Uptake in Hydrogen-Bonded Metal-Organic Cubes Possessing ACO and AST Zeolite-like Topologies
      Sava, Dorina F.; Kravtsov, Victor Ch.; Eckert, Juergen; Eubank, Jarrod F.; Nouar, Farid; Eddaoudi, Mohamed
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (30), 10394-10396CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Herein the authors detail a novel approach for targeting zeolite-like metal-org. frameworks (ZMOFs) that uses metal-org. cubes, which are regarded as double four-membered rings (d4Rs) and are composite building units (BUs) in traditional inorg. zeolites. Accordingly, the authors outline the successful implementation of this strategy by reporting two ZMOFs with ACO and AST zeolite-like topologies, which were constructed from d4R BUs exclusively held together by hydrogen bonds. Their porosity was evaluated, delineating high hydrogen uptake and exceptional stability for the two hydrogen-bonded materials.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXot12gtb0%253D&md5=39ed7ba5c79bee4bf5f06120573925d9
      (j) Thornton, A. W., Nairn, K. M., Hill, J. M., Hill, A. J., and Hill, M. R. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 10662
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3j
      Metal-organic frameworks impregnated with magnesium-decorated fullerenes for methane and hydrogen storage
      Thornton, Aaron W.; Nairn, Kate M.; Hill, James M.; Hill, Anita J.; Hill, Matthew R.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (30), 10662-10669CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A new concept is described for methane and hydrogen storage materials involving the incorporation of magnesium-decorated fullerenes within metal-org. frameworks (MOFs). The system is modeled using a novel approach underpinned by surface potential energies developed from Lennard-Jones parameters. Impregnation of MOF pores with magnesium-decorated Mg10C60 fullerenes, denoted as Mg-C60@MOF, places exposed metal sites with high heats of gas adsorption into intimate contact with large surface area MOF structures. Perhaps surprisingly, given the void space occupied by C60, this impregnation delivers remarkable gas uptake, according to our modeling, which predicts exceptional performance for the Mg-C60@MOF family of materials. These predictions include a volumetric methane uptake of 265 vol./vol., the highest reported value for any material, which significantly exceeds the U.S. Department of Energy target of 180 vol./vol. We also predict a very high hydrogen adsorption enthalpy of 11 kJ mol-1 with relatively little decrease as a function of H2 filling. This value is close to the calcd. optimum value of 15.1 kJ mol-1 and is achieved concurrently with satn. hydrogen uptake in large amts. at pressures under 10 atm.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      (k) Jin, P., Dalgarno, S. J., Barnes, C., Teat, S. J., and Atwood, J. L. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2008, 130, 17262
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Ion Transport to the Interior of Metal-Organic Pyrogallol[4]arene Nanocapsules
      Jin, Ping; Dalgarno, Scott J.; Barnes, Charles; Teat, Simon J.; Atwood, Jerry L.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (51), 17262-17263CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Metal ions (Cs+) or ion pairs (Ag+ NO3-) are transported to the interior of gallium metal-org. pyrogallol[4]arene nanocapsules via aq. gates. This transport was studied by x-ray crystallog. and shows the affinity of the ions to reside deep in the polyarom. regions of the assemblies.

      Hydrogen-bonded pyrogallo[4]arene hexameric nanocapsules self-assemble into spheres, tubules, and combinations of both on the sub-micron scale. These assemblies were characterized by using dynamic light scattering, SEM, transmission electron microscopy, and at. force microscopy techniques.

      A hydrogen-bonded hexameric nanotoroidal assembly
      McKinlay, Robert M.; Atwood, Jerry L.
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2007), 46 (14), 2394-2397CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Reaction of tetrabenzyl-tetrabromocalix[4]arene with an excess of n-BuLi and tri-Me borate gave after treatment with HCl tetrabenzyl-(A,C-dibromo-B,D-diboronic acid)calix[4]arene in 85% yield. Six calix[4]arene mols. self-assemble into a large hexameric torus-shaped structure through H bonds. The doughnut assembly shows a noteworthy structural similarity to cucurbit[6]uril in the solid state and therefore may be viewed as a noncovalent analog.

      Prospective for biodegradable microstructured optical fibers
      Dupuis, Alexandre; Guo, Ning; Gao, Yan; Godbout, Nicolas; Lacroix, Suzanne; Dubois, Charles; Skorobogatiy, Maskim
      Optics Letters (2007), 32 (2), 109-111CODEN: OPLEDP; ISSN:0146-9592. (Optical Society of America)
      We report fabrication of a novel microstructured optical fiber made of biodegradable and water sol. materials that features ∼1 dB/cm transmission loss. Two cellulose butyrate tubes sepd. with hydroxypropyl cellulose powder were codrawn into a porous double-core fiber offering integration of optical, microfluidic, and potentially drug release functionalities.

      Metal organic frameworks as NO delivery materials for biological applications
      Hinks, Nathan J.; McKinlay, Alistair C.; Xiao, Bo; Wheatley, Paul S.; Morris, Russell E.
      Microporous and Mesoporous Materials (2009), 129 (3), 330-334CODEN: MIMMFJ; ISSN:1387-1811. (Elsevier Inc.)
      A review. Metal org. frameworks (MOFs) are highly porous materials that can store significant amts. of gas, including nitric oxide. The chem. compn. and toxicol. of many (but not all) of these materials makes them potentially suitable for medical applications. In this paper, the authors will describe how triggered release methods can be used to deliver biol. relevant amts. of NO and then show how Ni, Co and Cu-contg. MOFs are biol. active materials with potential applications in several different areas (anti-thrombosis, dermatol. and wound healing, anti-bacterial, vasodilation etc.). The authors will also discuss the pros and cons of MOFs, including their chem. and biol. stability and the toxicol. of MOFs in general.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXjslCqug%253D%253D&md5=a0aa293319412494352556c1473e1f6e

      4c
      Flexible Porous Metal-Organic Frameworks for a Controlled Drug Delivery
      Horcajada, Patricia; Serre, Christian; Maurin, Guillaume; Ramsahye, Naseem A.; Balas, Francisco; Vallet-Regi, Marila; Sebban, Muriel; Taulelle, Francis; Ferey, Geard
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (21), 6774-6780CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Flexible nanoporous chromium or iron terephthalates (BDC) MIL-53(Cr, Fe) or M(OH)[BDC] have been used as matrixes for the adsorption and in vitro drug delivery of Ibuprofen (or α-p-isobutylphenylpropionic acid). Both MIL-53(Cr) and MIL-53(Fe) solids adsorb around 20 wt % of Ibuprofen (Ibuprofen/dehydrated MIL-53 molar ratio = 0.22(1)), indicating that the amt. of inserted drug does not depend on the metal (Cr, Fe) constitutive of the hybrid framework. Structural and spectroscopic characterizations are provided for the solid filled with Ibuprofen. In each case, the very slow and complete delivery of Ibuprofen was achieved under physiol. conditions after 3 wk with a predictable zero-order kinetics, which highlights the unique properties of flexible hybrid solids for adapting their pore opening to optimize the drug-matrix interactions.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXlsValt7c%253D&md5=1874dd12aa2a23e5c982b8549f5cfae1
      (d) Lin, W., Rieter, W., and Taylor, K. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2009, 48, 650
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4d
      Modular synthesis of functional nanoscale coordination polymers
      Lin, Wenbin; Rieter, J. William; Taylor, Kathryn M. L.
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2009), 48 (4), 650-658CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A review. The coordination-directed assembly of metal ions and org. bridging ligands has afforded a variety of bulk-scale hybrid materials with promising characteristics for a no. of practical applications, such as gas storage and heterogeneous catalysis. Recently, so-called coordination polymers have emerged as a new class of hybrid nanomaterials. The authors highlight advances in the syntheses of both amorphous and cryst. nanoscale coordination polymers and illustrate how scaling down these materials to the nano-regime has enabled their use in a abroad range of applications including catalysis, spin-crossover, templating, biosensing, biomedical imaging, and anti-cancer drug delivery. These results underscore the exciting opportunities of developing next-generation functional nanomaterials based on mol. components.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsVCqu7o%253D&md5=43ce407aaa8dc8b75946db7ffe2a8819

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4e
      Controlling interpenetration in metal-organic frameworks by liquid-phase epitaxy
      Shekhah, Osama; Wang, Hui; Paradinas, Markos; Ocal, Carmen; Schuepbach, Bjoern; Terfort, Andreas; Zacher, Denise; Fischer, Roland A.; Woell, Christof
      Nature Materials (2009), 8 (6), 481-484CODEN: NMAACR; ISSN:1476-1122. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are highly porous materials generally consisting of two building elements: inorg. coupling units and org. linkers. These frameworks offer an enormous porosity, which can be used to store large amts. of gases and, as demonstrated in more recent applications, makes these compds. suitable for drug release. The huge sizes of the pores inside MOFs, however, also give rise to a fundamental complication, the formation of sublattices occupying the same space. This interpenetration greatly reduces the pore size and thus the available space within the MOF structure. The authors demonstrate here by the prepn. of microporous MOF-508 [Zn(bdc)(bipy)0.5] (bdc = 1,4 benzenedicarboxylate, bipy = 4,4'-bipyridine) that the formation of the 2nd, interpenetrated framework can be suppressed by using LPE on an org. template. This success demonstrates the potential of the step-by-step method to synthesize new classes of MOFs not accessible by conventional solvothermal methods.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXmtFemsL4%253D&md5=d29cb0b80fa8d213267690fc5af22c6d
      (f) Taylor-Pashow, K. M. L., Rocca, J. D., Xie, Z., Tran, S., and Lin, W. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 14261
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4f
      Postsynthetic Modifications of Iron-Carboxylate Nanoscale Metal-Organic Frameworks for Imaging and Drug Delivery
      Taylor-Pashow, Kathryn M. L.; Della Rocca, Joseph; Xie, Zhigang; Tran, Sylvie; Lin, Wenbin
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (40), 14261-14263CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Fe(III)-carboxylate nanoscale metal-org. frameworks (NMOFs) with the MIL-101 structure were synthesized using a solvothermal technique with microwave heating. The ∼200 nm particles were characterized using a variety of methods, including SEM, PXRD, nitrogen adsorption measurements, TGA, and EDX. By replacing a percentage of the bridging ligand (terephthalic acid) with 2-amino terephthalic acid, amine groups were incorporated into the framework to provide sites for covalent attachment of biol. relevant cargoes while still maintaining the MIL-101 structure. In proof-of-concept expts., an optical contrast agent (a BODIPY dye) and an ethoxysuccinato-cisplatin anticancer prodrug were successfully incorporated into the Fe(III)-carboxylate NMOFs via postsynthetic modifications of the as-synthesized particles. These cargoes are released upon the degrdn. of the NMOF frameworks, and the rate of cargo release was controlled by coating the NMOF particles with a silica shell. Potential utility of the new NMOF-based nanodelivery vehicles for optical imaging and anticancer therapy was demonstrated in vitro using HT-29 human colon adenocarcinoma cells.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtFCjt77L&md5=baa2e1455cfccdfe188c108f37bfae2a
      (g) Vallet-Regí, M., Balas, F., and Arcos, D. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2007, 46, 7548
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4g
      Mesoporous materials for drug delivery
      Vallet-Regi, Maria; Balas, Francisco; Arcos, Daniel
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2007), 46 (40), 7548-7558CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A review. Research on mesoporous materials for biomedical purposes has experienced an outstanding increase during recent years. Since 2001, when MCM-41 was first proposed as drug-delivery system, silica-based materials, such as SBA-15 or MCM-48, and some metal-org. frameworks were discussed as drug carriers and controlled-release systems. Mesoporous materials are intended for both systemic-delivery systems and implantable local-delivery devices. The later application provides very promising possibilities in the field of bone-tissue repair because of the excellent behavior of these materials as bioceramics. This Minireview deals with the advances in this field by the control of the textural parameters, surface functionalization, and the synthesis of sophisticated stimuli-response systems.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhtF2ku7jO&md5=0684ce2ab609759cec424df322647b33

      5b
      Temperature-triggered gate opening for gas adsorption in microporous manganese formate
      Kim, Hyunuk; Samsonenko, Denis G.; Yoon, Minyoung; Yoon, Ji Woong; Hwang, Young Kyu; Chang, Jong-San; Kim, Kimoon
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2008), (39), 4697-4699CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Microporous manganese formate shows temp.-triggered gate opening for nitrogen and argon adsorption, which is not due to a structural change of the framework but due to dynamic opening of the pore aperture and/or sufficient kinetic energy of the adsorbates to overcome a diffusion barrier above a crit. temp.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtF2mtr3I&md5=3e4d0a2799148d9618130abb7d5533f1
      (c) Li, K., Olson, D. H., Lee, J. Y., Bi, W., Wu, K., Yuen, T., Xu, Q., and Li, J. Adv. Funct. Mater. 2008, 18, 2205
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5c
      Multifunctional microporous MOFs exhibiting gas/hydrocarbon adsorption selectivity, separation capability and three-dimensional magnetic ordering
      Li, Kunhao; Olson, David H.; Lee, Jeong Yong; Bi, Wenhua; Wu, Ke; Yuen, Tan; Xu, Qiang; Li, Jing
      Advanced Functional Materials (2008), 18 (15), 2205-2214CODEN: AFMDC6; ISSN:1616-301X. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Microporous materials [M3(HCOO)6]·DMF (M = Mn, Co, Ni) were synthesized solvothermally and structurally characterized by single crystal and powder x-ray diffraction methods. The metal network exhibits diamondoid connectivity and the overall framework gives rise to zigzag channels along the b axis where guest DMF mols. reside. The effective pore size of these channels is ∼5-6 Å. The materials feature high thermal stability and permanent porosity with relatively small pore diams. which are attributed to the extensive strong dative bonding between the metal centers and formate mols. The title compds. exhibit interesting multi-fold gas adsorption and magnetic properties. The adsorption study of alcs., aroms., and linear hydrocarbons revealed strong control of the adsorbent channel structures on their adsorption capacity and selectivity. The study also indicated possibility of using these materials for sepn. of close boiling chems. (e.g., ethylbenzene and p-xylene) via pressure swing adsorption (PSA) process and mols. with different diffusion parameters via kinetic-based process. Three-dimensional spontaneous magnetic ordering was found in all three network structures studied and at ground states they behave somewhat like soft magnets.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtVykt7rI&md5=d61851a5433f9b70e37ce7db069c5f4f
      (d) Wang, Z., Zhang, B., Kurmoo, M., Green, M. A., Fujiwara, H., Otsuka, T., and Kobayashi, H. Inorg. Chem. 2005, 44, 1230
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5d
      Synthesis and Characterization of a Porous Magnetic Diamond Framework, Co3(HCOO)6, and Its N2 Sorption Characteristic
      Wang, Zheming; Zhang, Bin; Kurmoo, Mohamedally; Green, Mark A.; Fujiwara, Hideki; Otsuka, Takeo; Kobayashi, Hayao
      Inorganic Chemistry (2005), 44 (5), 1230-1237CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      [Co3(HCOO)6](CH3OH)(H2O) (1), the isostructural analog of the porous magnet of coordination framework [Mn3(HCOO)6](CH3OH)(H2O), and its desolvated form [Co3(HCOO)6] (2) were prepd. and characterized by x-ray and neutron diffraction methods, IR, thermal analyses, and BET, and their magnetic properties were measured. The parent compd. 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system, space group P21/c, a 11.254(2), b 9.832(1), c 18.108(3) Å, β 127.222(2)°, Z = 4, R1 = 0.0329 at 180 K. It possesses a unit cell vol. that is 9% smaller than [Mn3(HCOO)6](CH3OH)(H2O) due to the smaller radius of Co2+ ion. Compared with the parent compd. 1, the desolvated compd. 2 has slightly larger lattice with cell parameters of a 11.2858(4), b 9.8690(4), c 18.1797(6) Å, β 127.193(2)°, V = 1613.0(1) Å3, R1 = 0.0356 at 180 K. The cell parameters of 2, obtained from neutron powder data at 2 K, are a 11.309(2), b 9.869(1), c 18.201(3) Å, β 127.244(8)°, V = 1617.3(5) Å3. The pore vol. reduces 33-30% by replacing Mn by Co. The material exhibits a diamond framework based on Co-centered CoCo4 tetrahedral nodes, in which all metal ions have octahedral coordination geometry and all HCOO groups link the metal ions in syn-syn/anti modes. It displays thermal stability up to 270°. The compd. easily loses guest mols. without loss of crystallinity, and it partly reabsorbs water from the atm. Significant N2 sorption was obsd. for the desolvated framework suggesting that the material possesses permanent porosity. The magnetic properties show a tendency to a 3-dimensional long-range magnetic ordering, probably antiferromagnetic with a spin canting arrangement <2 K.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXht1Omtb0%253D&md5=344dd2626388f9b496e3d05285ef8edf
      (e) Wang, Z. M., Zhang, Y. J., Liu, T., Kurmoo, M., and Gao, S. Adv. Funct. Mater. 2007, 17, 1523
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5e
      [Fe3(HCOO)6]: a permanent porous diamond framework displaying H2/N2 adsorption, guest inclusion, and guest-dependent magnetism
      Wang, Zheming; Zhang, Yanjuan; Liu, Tao; Kurmoo, Mohamedally; Gao, Song
      Advanced Functional Materials (2007), 17 (9), 1523-1536CODEN: AFMDC6; ISSN:1616-301X. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      The porous magnet [Fe3(HCOO)6], the iron member of the [M3(HCOO)6] family (where M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, etc.), based on a diamond framework consisting of Fe-centered FeFe4 tetrahedral nodes, is prepd. successfully by using a soln.-chem. method. The as-prepd. compd., [Fe3(HCOO)6](CH3OH)1.5(H2O)0.5 (1-parent), exhibits facile removal of its guests, methanol, and water, to give the desolvated framework [Fe3(HCOO)6] (2-empty) that displays permanent porosity and thermal stability up to 270°C. The flexibility of the framework and the amphiphilic nature of the surface of the pores consisting of both C-H and O arrays allows 2-empty to take up significant H2 and N2 at liq.-nitrogen temps. and a wide spectrum of both polar and nonpolar guests of different sizes. A series of guest-inclusion compds., [Fe3(HCOO)6](I2)0.84 (3-iodine), [Fe3(HCOO)6](C4H8O) (4-THF), [Fe3(HCOO)6](C4H4O) (5-furan), [Fe3(HCOO)6](C6H6) (6-benzene), [Fe3(HCOO)6](CH3CN) (7-acetonitrile), and [Fe3(HCOO)6]((CH3)2CO) (8-acetone) are successfully prepd. by vapor diffusion of the guest into the pores of 2-empty and their structures are characterized by using single-crystal X-ray crystallog. Zigzag mol. arrays of the guest are formed in the confined channels of the host framework, and the weak hydrogen-bonding provides the main host-guest interaction. All the compds. show 3D long-range magnetic ordering and guest-modulated Curie temps., coercive fields, and remnant magnetization as a consequence of the subtle rearrangement of the magnetic framework that conforms to the size of the guests and the difference in host-guest interactions. A possible magnetic structure of the framework is proposed to account for magnetic competition and geometrical frustration. The thermal and spectroscopic properties of the compds. are also reported.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXnvVWrtrc%253D&md5=77d85fce0a4970dd80f0511df2b1cbe8
    6. 6
      (a) Chizallet, C. l., Lazare, S., Bazer-Bachi, D., Bonnier, F., Lecocq, V., Soyer, E., Quoineaud, A.-A., and Bats, N. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2010, 132, 12365
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6a
      Catalysis of Transesterification by a Nonfunctionalized Metal-Organic Framework: Acido-Basicity at the External Surface of ZIF-8 Probed by FTIR and ab Initio Calculations
      Chizallet, Celine; Lazare, Sandrine; Bazer-Bachi, Delphine; Bonnier, Fabien; Lecocq, Vincent; Soyer, Emmanuel; Quoineaud, Anne-Agathe; Bats, Nicolas
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (35), 12365-12377CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The zeolite imidazolate framework ZIF-8 is shown for the first time to be able to catalyze transesterification of vegetable oil with significant activity. Rationalization of this behavior at the at. scale is provided by combining CO adsorption monitored by FTIR and DFT calcns. (clusters and periodic models). We demonstrate that the acido-basic sites are located at the external surface of the material or at defects, but not in the microporosity of ZIF-8. A great variety of sites are found the surface: OH and NH groups, hydrogenocarbonates, low-coordinated Zn atoms, and free N- moieties belonging to linkers. Their proportions depend on the operating conditions (temp. and pressure). The acido-basicity of the surface is then probed by adsorption of CO at low temp. In parallel, the species present are mapped by DFT calcns. combined with a thermodn. model. An assignment of the CO region of the FTIR spectra can thus be proposed. The complex IR spectrum is attributed to the coexistence of classical C-adducts of CO with acid sites and other modes on basic sites (O-adducts and side-on adducts). Adsorption energies and CO frequency shifts show that some strong Lewis sites exist (in particular ZnII species), as well as strong Bronsted acid sites (NH groups), together with basic sites (OH groups and N- moieties). By calcg. the co-adsorption of a model ester (Me acetate) and methanol, we show the prevailing role of ZnII species as acid sites, combined with N- moieties and OH groups as basic ones, in detg. the catalytic properties of ZIF-8. This work opens new perspectives on the use of MOFs in catalysis and, more generally, on the properties of their external surface.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtVOnsr%252FP&md5=95d89570c7499ed2b2031702a6d3cab0
      (b) Cho, S.-H., Ma, B., Nguyen, S. T., Hupp, J. T., and Albrecht-Schmitt, T. E. Chem. Commun. 2006, 2563
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6b
      A metal-organic framework material that functions as an enantioselective catalyst for olefin epoxidation
      Cho, So-Hye; Ma, Baoqing; Nguyen, SonBinh T.; Hupp, Joseph T.; Albrecht-Schmitt, Thomas E.
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2006), (24), 2563-2565CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A new microporous metal-org. framework compd. featuring chiral (salen)Mn struts is highly effective as an asym. catalyst for olefin epoxidn., yielding enantiomeric excesses that rival those of the free mol. analog. Framework confinement of the manganese salen entity enhances catalyst stability, imparts substrate size selectivity, and permits catalyst sepn. and reuse.

      6c
      A homochiral metal-organic material with permanent porosity, enantioselective sorption properties, and catalytic activity
      Dybtsev, Danil N.; Nuzhdin, Alexey L.; Chun, Hyungphil; Bryliakov, Konstantin P.; Talsi, Evgeniy P.; Fedin, Vladimir P.; Kim, Kimoon
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2006), 45 (6), 916-920CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A new synthetic approach starting from readily available chems. (zinc dinitrate hexahydrate, L-lactic acid, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid) successfully produces a robust homochiral metal-org. microporous framework. The material exhibits size- and enantioselective guest-sorption properties, as well as remarkable catalytic activity with size- and chemoselectivity, and high conversion in the oxidn. of thioethers to sulfoxides.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhsFKmsL8%253D&md5=8072ca11e056d03218d2d1239162bec2
      (d) Hoskins, B. F. and Robson, R. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1990, 112, 1546
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6d
      Design and construction of a new class of scaffolding-like materials comprising infinite polymeric frameworks of 3D-linked molecular rods. A reappraisal of the zinc cyanide and cadmium cyanide structures and the synthesis and structure of the diamond-related frameworks [N(CH3)4][CuIZnII(CN)4] and CuI[4,4',4'',4'''-tetracyanotetraphenylmethane]BF4.xC6H5NO2
      Hoskins, B. F.; Robson, Richard
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1990), 112 (4), 1546-54CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
      It is proposed that a new and potentially extensive class of scaffolding-like materials may be afforded by linking together centers with either a tetrahedral or an octahedral array of valences by rodlike connecting units. Some simple general principles concerning the design and construction of these frameworks are presented together with reasons for expecting them to show unusual and useful properties. Two of the simplest conceivable systems of this type are isomorphous Zn(CN)2 and Cd(CN)2 whose structures were reexamd. by single-crystal x-ray diffraction, confirming the earlier description based on powder diffraction data of 2 interpenetrating diamond-related frameworks: cubic, space group P‾43m, Z = 2; with a 5.9002(9) Å (Zn(CN)2) and 6.301(1) Å (Cd(CN)2); 2 unique metal centers, 1 surrounded tetrahedrally by 4C and the other by 4N donors; MCNM rods linear; Zn-C 1.923(6), Zn-N 2.037(5), Cd-C 2.099(5), Cd-N 2.196(4), C-N 1.150(5) Å in Zn(CN)2, and 1.162(5) Å in Cd(CN)2. The interpenetration of sep. frameworks demonstrated in these archetypal structures is likely to be a major concern in future studies of more complex scaffolding materials. [N(CH3)4][CuZn(CN)4] was deliberately designed to demonstrate one conceivable way of preventing interpenetration; it is cubic, space group F‾43m, with A 11.609(3) Å; Z = 4. The structure contains a single diamond-related framework with alternating tetrahedral Cu(I) and Zn(II) centers and linear rods that are very likely of the type CuCNZn with bond distances Cu-C 1.877(8) and Zn-N 2.069(15) Å, Z(CH3)4+ ions occupy half the adamantane cavities generated by the framework, the remaining cavities being vacant. CuI[4,4',4'',4'''-tetracyanotetraphenylmethane]BF4·xC6H5NO2 (x ≥ 7.7) represents the first attempt to generate an infinite 3-dimensional framework with rods of some complexity. It is tetragonal, space group I‾4m2, with a 13.620(2) and c 22.642(2) Å; Z = 2. The structure contains a diamond-related cationic framework with C·C6H4·CN·Cu rods of length 8.856(2) Å. The framework is tetragonally elongated along the c axis apparently as a result of nonbonded interactions between the 8 ortho-H atoms around the methane C centers. There is no interpenetration. The framework generates very large adamantane-like cavities occupied by disordered C6H5NO2 (at least 7.7 mols. per Cu) together with BF4- ions. The crystals undergo ready anion exchange. The material is unusual in that approx. two thirds by vol. of what is undoubtedly a crystal is effectively liq. The results provide confidence that a wide range of scaffolding-like solids should prove accessible.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3cXovVOjtw%253D%253D&md5=2a9efabcd93072e8668a50199c51320c
      (e) Hwang, Y., Hong, D. Y., Chang, J. S., Jhung, S., Seo, Y. K., Kim, J., Vimont, A., Daturi, M., Serre, C., and Férey, G. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2008, 120, 4212

      (f) Tanabe, K. K. and Cohen, S. M. Inorg. Chem. 2010, 49, 6766
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6f
      Modular, Active, and Robust Lewis Acid Catalysts Supported on a Metal-Organic Framework
      Tanabe, Kristine K.; Cohen, Seth M.
      Inorganic Chemistry (2010), 49 (14), 6766-6774CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) showed promise as heterogeneous catalysts because of their high crystallinity, uniform pores, and ability to be chem. and phys. tuned for specific chem. transformations. One of the challenges with MOF-based catalysis is few systems achieve all of the desired features for a heterogeneous catalyst, including high activity, robustness (recyclability), and excellent selectivity. Herein, postsynthetic modification (PSM) of a MOF was used to synthesize MOF catalysts that are highly robust and active for epoxide ring-opening reactions. In the following study, four metalated MOFs (UMCM-1-AMInpz, UMCM-1-AMInsal, UMCM-1-AMFesal, and UMCM-1-AMCupz) were examd. as catalysts for β-azido and β-amino alc. synthesis with epoxides of varying sizes and shapes using two different nucleophiles (TMSN3 and aniline). The four MOFs are isostructural, exhibit good thermal and structural stability, and display different catalytic activities based on the combination of metal ion and chelating ligand immobilized within the framework. In particular, UMCM-1-AMInpz and UMCM-1-AMInsal act as robust, single-site catalysts with distinct selectivity for ring-opening reactions with specific nucleophiles. More importantly, one of these catalysts, UMCM-1-AMInpz, selectively promotes the ring-opening of cis-stilbene oxide in the presence of trans-stilbene oxide, which cannot be achieved with a comparable mol. Lewis acid catalyst. PSM is a promising, modular, and highly tunable approach for the discovery of robust, active, and selective MOF catalysts that combine the best aspects of homogeneous and heterogeneous systems.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXns1Cms7w%253D&md5=f8d7129cf25fbadf121c416a80c8c8c9
      (g) Wu, C. D. and Lin, W. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2007, 46, 1075
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6g
      Heterogeneous asymmetric catalysis with homochiral metal-organic frameworks: Network-structure-dependent catalytic activity
      Wu, Chuan-De; Lin, Wenbin
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2007), 46 (7), 1075-1078CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      The prepn. and crystal structure of two homochiral highly porous metal-org. framework cadmium complexes, [Cd3L4(NO3)6]·7MeOH·5H2O and [CdL2(H2O)2](ClO4)2·DMF·4MeOH·3H2O (L = (R)-6,6'-dichloro-4,4'-dipyridinyl-1,1'-binaphthalene-2,2'-diol), are reported. The heterogeneous asym. catalysts which are formed from the same building blocks show remarkably different activity. Although both catalysts are based on 2-fold interpenetrated structures, upon treatment with Ti(OPr-i)4, one catalyzes the addn. of diethylzinc to arom. aldehydes with high enantioselectivity (up to 90% ee), while the other is inactive.

      6h
      A Homochiral Porous Metal-Organic Framework for Highly Enantioselective Heterogeneous Asymmetric Catalysis
      Wu, Chuan-De; Hu, Aiguo; Zhang, Lin; Lin, Wenbin
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (25), 8940-8941CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A homochiral porous noninterpenetrating metal-org. framework (MOF) was constructed by linking infinite 1D [Cd(μ-Cl)2]n zigzag chains with axially chiral bipyridine bridging ligands contg. orthogonal secondary functional groups. The secondary chiral dihydroxy groups accessible via the large open channels in the MOF were used to generate a heterogeneous asym. catalyst for the addn. of diethyzinc to arom. aldehydes to afford chiral secondary alcs. at ≤ 93% enantiomeric excess. Control expts. with dendritic arom. aldehydes of different sizes indicate that the heterogeneous asym. catalyst derived from the MOF is both highly active and enantioselective as a result of the creation of readily accessible, uniform active catalyst sites inside the porous MOF.

      8b
      Cadmium-113 shielding tensors of oxo cadmium compounds. 2. Single-crystal studies on cadmium calcium tetraacetate hexahydrate, cadmium maleate dihydrate, cadmium formate dihydrate, cadmium diammonium disulfate hexahydrate, and cadmium diacetate dihydrate
      Honkonen, Robert S.; Ellis, Paul D.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1984), 106 (19), 5488-97CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
      Crystals of the title compds. were investigated by using single-crystal oriented 113Cd NMR. The orientation of 6 distinct 113Cd shielding tensors in the resp. mol. ref. frames was detd. In each case, the tensor configuration complied with the Cd site symmetry. Tensor-lattice site orientations for Cd Ca tetraacetate and Cd maleate were unambiguously detd. via NMR and crystallog. data. The 113Cd NMR of Cd formate, Cd(NH4)2(SO4)2, and Cd acetate crystals gave rise to symmetry-related tensors. A qual. method for making symmetry-related tensor-lattice site assignments is introduced and employed for these Cd salts. The magnitude and orientation of the principal elements of the 113Cd shielding tensor are discussed in terms of the structural features of the corresponding oxocadmium ref. frame and tensor element-structure correlations are proposed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      8d
      Structure of Anhydrous Alkali-Metal Formates
      Wilson, Michael P.; Alcock, Nathaniel W.; Rodger, P. Mark
      Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (11), 4359-4363CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Single-crystal x-ray diffraction has yielded new crystal structures for Cs formate (CsOOCH) and Rb formate (RbOOCH). The Cs formate structure has the same unit cell and space group as that published from powder x-ray diffraction data (Masuda, Y.; Yahata, A.; Ogawa, H. Inorg. Chem. 1995, 34, 3130-3133) but differs radically in the placement and orientation of the formate ions. The new crystal structure was successfully modeled with an empirical force field based on pair potentials, whereas it proved impossible to develop a force field that gave an adequate description of the powder structure. For Rb formate, the gross structure is similar to that previously published (Masuda, Y.; Morita, W.; Yahata, A.; Yukawa, Y. Thermochim. Acta 1998, 318, 39-43), but the space group includes a mirror plane (Pbcm rather than Pbc21). From this information, the authors were able to analyze the effect of the cation size on the crystal structure for alkali-metal formates.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      8f
      The crystal structure of cupric formate tetrahydrate, Cu(HCO2)2.4H2O
      Kiriyama, Ryoichi; Ibamoto, Hideko; Matsuo, Kanji
      Acta Crystallographica (1954), 7 (), 482-3CODEN: ACCRA9; ISSN:0365-110X.
      The crystal structure was detd. by Patterson and Fourier syntheses and refined by Fo - Fc syntheses. Each Cu atom is surrounded by 4 oxygen atoms and 4 different formate ions in an approx. square configuration and by 2 water mols. at a greater distance. The formate ion is nearly sym. with an O.sbd.C.sbd.O angle of 120°.

      8i
      Cadmium-113 shielding tensors of oxo cadmium compounds. 2. Single-crystal studies on cadmium calcium tetraacetate hexahydrate, cadmium maleate dihydrate, cadmium formate dihydrate, cadmium diammonium disulfate hexahydrate, and cadmium diacetate dihydrate
      Honkonen, Robert S.; Ellis, Paul D.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1984), 106 (19), 5488-97CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
      Crystals of the title compds. were investigated by using single-crystal oriented 113Cd NMR. The orientation of 6 distinct 113Cd shielding tensors in the resp. mol. ref. frames was detd. In each case, the tensor configuration complied with the Cd site symmetry. Tensor-lattice site orientations for Cd Ca tetraacetate and Cd maleate were unambiguously detd. via NMR and crystallog. data. The 113Cd NMR of Cd formate, Cd(NH4)2(SO4)2, and Cd acetate crystals gave rise to symmetry-related tensors. A qual. method for making symmetry-related tensor-lattice site assignments is introduced and employed for these Cd salts. The magnitude and orientation of the principal elements of the 113Cd shielding tensor are discussed in terms of the structural features of the corresponding oxocadmium ref. frame and tensor element-structure correlations are proposed.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL2cXlsValsL8%253D&md5=61a5d0d221e0240a687f36e3ee95f2ed
      (j) Arii, T. and Kishi, A. Thermochim. Acta 1999, 325, 157
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8j
      Thermal dehydration of cobalt and zinc formate dihydrates by controlled-rate thermogravimetry (CRTG) and simultaneous x-ray diffractometry-differential scanning calorimetry (XRD-DSC)
      Arii, Tadashi; Kishi, Akira
      Thermochimica Acta (1999), 325 (2), 157-165CODEN: THACAS; ISSN:0040-6031. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
      The thermal dehydration study of the similar hydrated salts, cobalt and zinc formate dihydrates, have been carried out successfully by means of x-ray diffractometry-differential scanning calorimetry (XRD-DSC) and controlled-rate thermogravimetry (CRTG). X-ray diffraction anal. recorded simultaneously indicates that the resulting anhyd. product, Zn(HCO2)2, was cryst., while Co(HCO2)2 was amorphous. The XRD-DSC data are proven to be invaluable in verifying the interpretation of overlapping processes in thermal events. In addn., these differences in the resulting anhyd. products can be explained from kinetic anal. results based on the CRTG data. The kinetic mechanism governing the dehydration of zinc formate dihydrate is a nucleation and growth process, while in the case of cobalt formate dihydrate a phase boundary controlled reaction is the governing mechanism.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      9a
      Three metal-organic frameworks prepared from mixed solvents of DMF and HAc
      He, Jianghua; Zhang, Yuetao; Pan, Qinhe; Yu, Jihong; Ding, Hong; Xu, Ruren
      Microporous and Mesoporous Materials (2006), 90 (1-3), 145-152CODEN: MIMMFJ; ISSN:1387-1811. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Three metal-org. framework compds., [HZn3(OH)(BTC)2(H2O)2(DMF)]·H2O (MOF-CJ3), [Co6(BTC)2(HCOO)6(DMF)6] (MOF-CJ4), and [Co18(HCOO)36]·3H2O (MOF-CJ5), were solvothermally synthesized in mixed solvents of DMF and HAc, resp. These MOFs were characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction, x-ray powder diffraction, ICP, TG analyses, IR, and photoluminescence spectroscopy analyses. MOF-CJ3 crystallizes in tetragonal, space group I4cm with a 20.588(3), b 20.588(3), c 17.832(4) Å. Its framework can be described as a 3-dimensional decorated (3,6)-connected net based on the assembly of trigonal prismatic SBUs and triangular links. MOF-CJ4 crystallizes in hexagonal, space group P-3 with a 13.975(2), b 13.975(2), c 8.1650(16) Å. The 2-dimensional network of MOF-CJ4 is constructed from [Co6(R(CO2)3)2(HCO2)6(DMF)6] (R = C9H3-) clusters and 1,3,5-benzene-tricarboxylates linkers. MOF-CJ5 crystallizes in triclinic, space group P‾1 with a 15.205(3), b 18.005(4), c 21.500(4) Å, α 71.21(3), β 84.47(3), γ 67.15(3)°. MOF-CJ5 has a diamond framework with Co-centered CoCo4 tetrahedra as nodes. It is noteworthy that the formic ligands in MOF-CJ4 and MOF-CJ5 are generated by the decompn. of DMF under acid conditions and incorporated into these two compds.

      Mn3(HCOO)6, a 3-dimensional highly stable and flexible porous diamondoid framework based on Mn-centered MnMn4 tetrahedral nodes, exhibits a wide spectrum of guest inclusion behavior and long-range magnetic ordering with guest-modulated crit. temp.

      [CH3NH2(CH2)2NH2CH3][M2(HCOO)6] (M = MnII and CoII): weak ferromagnetic metal formate frameworks of unique binodal 6-connected (412.63)(49.66) topology, templated by a diammonium cation
      Wang, Zheming; Zhang, Xueyu; Batten, Stuart R.; Kurmoo, Mohamedally; Gao, Song
      Inorganic Chemistry (2007), 46 (21), 8439-8441CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Two compds. of [dmenH22+][M2(HCOO)62-] (M = MnII and CoII), synthesized using N,N'-dimethylethylenediammonium (dmenH22+) as the template, possess anionic metal formate frameworks of a novel binodal 6-connected (412.63)(49.66) topol. They are the first coordination examples of this unique network closely related to nicolite and colquiriite and exhibit 3-dimensional long-range antiferromagnetic ordering with small spin canting.

      10a
      Zeolite Synthesis Using Flexible Diquaternary Alkylammonium Ions (CnH2n+1)2HN+(CH2)5N+H(CnH2n+1)2 with n = 1-5 as Structure-Directing Agents
      Han, Bada; Lee, Song-Ho; Shin, Chae-Ho; Cox, Paul A.; Hong, Suk Bong
      Chemistry of Materials (2005), 17 (3), 477-486CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
      The use of flexible, linear diquaternary alkylammonium ions (CnH2n+1)2HN+(CH2)5N+H(CnH2n+1)2 with n = 1-5 as structure-directing agents in zeolite syntheses is described. Among the ammonium ions studied here, the Me2HN+(CH2)5N+HMe2 and [Me2CH]2HN+(CH2)5N+H[CHMe2]2 ions are new structure-directing agents for the crystn. of levyne and MCM-22, resp. The overall synthesis results of this study reveal that the phase selectivity of the crystn. can differ according to both the length of the dialkyl substituents on the ammonium ion and the oxide compn. of synthesis mixts. The host-guest interactions in nonasil, ZSM-12, mordenite, and levyne contg. Me2HN+(CH2)5N+HMe2 as a guest mol. were studied by 1H-13C CP MAS NMR and Raman spectroscopies, and computer modeling studies, and the org. guest mols. adopt distinct conformations to fit in the pores of each zeolite host.

      10b
      A combustion-free methodology for synthesizing zeolites and zeolite-like materials
      Lee, Hyunjoo; Zones, Stacey I.; Davis, Mark E.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2003), 425 (6956), 385-388CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      The authors report a synthetic methodol. that avoids high temps. in prepn. of synthetic zeolites by creating org. structure-directing agents (SDAs) that can be disassembled within the zeolite pore space to allow removal of their fragments for possible use again by reassembly. The methodol. is shown for the synthesis of zeolite ZSM-5 using a SDA that contains a cyclic ketal group that is removed from the SDA while it is inside the zeolite without destruction of the inorg. framework. This approach should be applicable to the synthesis of a wide variety of inorg. and organometallic structures.

      Multivariate approach to zeolite synthesis
      Tagliabue, Marco; Carluccio, Luciano Cosimo; Ghisletti, Danila; Perego, Carlo
      Catalysis Today (2003), 81 (3), 405-412CODEN: CATTEA; ISSN:0920-5861. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
      The influence of seven variables on the results of zeolite synthesis performed in presence of 1-methyl-1,4-tetramethylenebis(N-methylpiperidinium) dihydroxide as structure directing agent (SDA) was examd. The syntheses were planned according to a factorial design strategy and run by using a multiautoclave device. The produced data-set (exptl. factors values and qual. XRD responses for 72 syntheses) was explored by stepwise linear discriminant anal. (LDA): SiO2/Al2O3 molar ratio was identified as the most influent synthesis variable, discriminating between a region rich in amorphous materials and a region where the formation of MFI zeolite is favored.

      11a
      High-Throughput Synthesis of Zeolitic Imidazolate Frameworks and Application to CO2 Capture
      Banerjee, Rahul; Phan, Anh; Wang, Bo; Knobler, Carolyn; Furukawa, Hiroyasu; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2008), 319 (5865), 939-943CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      A high-throughput protocol was developed for the synthesis of zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs). Twenty-five different ZIF crystals were synthesized from only 9600 microreactions of either Zn(II)/Co(II) and imidazolate/imidazolate-type linkers. All of the ZIF structures have tetrahedral frameworks: 10 of which have two different links (heterolinks), 16 of which are previously unobserved compns. and structures, and 5 of which have topologies as yet unobserved in zeolites. Members of a selection of these ZIFs (termed ZIF-68, ZIF-69, and ZIF-70) have high thermal stability (up to 390°) and chem. stability in refluxing org. and aq. media. Their frameworks have high porosity (with surface areas up to 1970 square meters per g), and they exhibit unusual selectivity for CO2 capture from CO2/CO mixts. and extraordinary capacity for storing CO2: 1 L of ZIF-69 can hold ∼83 L of CO2 at 273 K under ambient pressure.

      (b) Greathouse, J. A. and Allendorf, M. D. J. Phys. Chem. C 2008, 112, 5795
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11b
      Force Field Validation for Molecular Dynamics Simulations of IRMOF-1 and Other Isoreticular Zinc Carboxylate Coordination Polymers
      Greathouse, Jeffery A.; Allendorf, Mark D.
      Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2008), 112 (15), 5795-5802CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
      Mol. dynamics simulations were conducted to validate a hybrid force field for metal-org. framework-5 (IRMOF-1). In this force field, only nonbonded parameters are used to describe Zn-O interactions. The CVFF force field was used with slight modifications to describe the benzene dicarboxylate linker. The force field correctly predicts a wide range of structural properties of this MOF, including a neg. thermal expansion of approx. 1% at 30 and 293 K, in agreement with both theory and expt. Compressibility results and the assocd. elastic moduli are in also good agreement with published d. functional theory calcns. and nanoindentation expts. The force field predicts a decrease in elastic moduli as temp. increases, which would greatly affect the mech. properties of MOFs. Calcd. vibrational frequencies for Zn-O modes agree with expt., and a low-frequency mode representing a 180° rotation of the Ph groups is seen. This rotation becomes more prevalent as the temp. is increased from 300 to 400 K, in agreement with NMR data. Simulations were also carried out with adsorbed guests, including ethanol, cyclohexane, and several chloromethanes. It is shown that the IRMOF-1 lattice parameter depends on the nature of the guest-framework interaction; strongly hydrophilic guests, such as ethanol, cause a decrease (-0.9%) in unit cell vol., while hydrophobic guests cause an increase (0.7-1.5%) in unit cell vol. The calcd. free vols. in IRMOF-1 range from 53.5% to 56.0%, in good agreement with expt. Finally, the activation energy for benzene self-diffusion calcd. at low loadings is in good agreement with previous simulations and NMR results, but the magnitude of the diffusion const. is underestimated, most likely because of deficiencies in the CVFF portion of the force field. The results demonstrate, however, that employing a rigid force field results in much poorer agreement with exptl. data. Addnl., a flexible force field approach is required when simulating framework stability because of phys. changes or the presence of adsorbates. The use of a general-purpose force field for the org. components allows our approach to be extended to other Zn-based frameworks.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Hybrid Open Networks (MIL 16): Synthesis, Crystal Structure, and Ferrimagnetism of Co4(OH)2(H2O)2(C4H4O4)3·2H2O, a New Layered Cobalt(II) Carboxylate with 14-Membered Ring Channels
      Livage, Carine; Egger, Chrystelle; Ferey, Gerard
      Chemistry of Materials (1999), 11 (6), 1546-1550CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
      A new layered cobalt succinate, Co4(OH)2(H2O)2(C4H4O4)3·2H2O, was prepd. under hydrothermal conditions at 180° from a 1:1.5:4:120 mixt. of Co(II) chloride hexahydrate, succinic acid, potassium hydroxide, and water. The structure was solved by single-crystal x-ray diffraction: space group P‾1, a 10.181(2), b 10.668(2), c 12.857(2) Å, α 112.97(3), β 91.24(3), γ 117.96(3)°, Z = 2, 5511 F2 values with I = 2σ(I), R1 = 0.045 and wR2 = 0.114. The title compd. presents a structure constituted by the stacking along [100] of metal oxide layers in which 14-membered ring windows appear. Succinate anions linked the cobalt atoms within each layer. From magnetization measurements, this compd. is ferrimagnetic <10 K.

      11e
      Hydrothermal versus Nonhydrothermal Synthesis for the Preparation of Organic-Inorganic Solids: The Example of Cobalt(II) Succinate
      Livage, Carine; Egger, Chrystelle; Ferey, Gerard
      Chemistry of Materials (2001), 13 (2), 410-414CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
      Hydrothermal technique was used together with a room-temp. process for the synthesis of Co-succinate compds. Four structures are described for two new compds.: K2Co(C4H4O4)2 and Co(H2O)4(C4H4O4). Whatever the soln. conditions, carboxylate ligands, which possess a strong nucleophilic character, coordinate each metal ion. However, the coordination ability of carboxylate under hydrothermal conditions is different from that under mild ones. For high-temp. phases, carboxylic groups are multidentate and the org. acts as a template during the condensation of the O-metal networks, whereas under room temp. conditions, they are unidentate and infinite structures were obtained via the bridging role of the ligand.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Livage, Carine; Guillou, Nathalie; Chaigneau, Julienne; Rabu, Pierre; Drillon, Marc; Ferey, Gerard
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2005), 44 (40), 6488-6491CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)

This structure provides a new example of the concept of scale chem., in which an {Na6Co6O26} super octahedron is connected in a classical ReO3 architecture.

      11g
      A cobalt(II) containing metal-organic framework showing catalytic activity in oxidation reactions
      Lu, Ying; Tonigold, Markus; Bredenkoetter, Bjoern; Volkmer, Dirk; Hitzbleck, Julia; Langstein, Gerhard
      Zeitschrift fuer Anorganische und Allgemeine Chemie (2008), 634 (12-13), 2411-2417CODEN: ZAACAB; ISSN:0044-2313. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A metal-org. framework (MOF) contg. redox active CoII atoms, [CoII(BPB)]·3DMF (1), was prepd. from the solvothermal reaction of CoII nitrate and 1,4-bis(4'-pyrazolyl)benzene (H2-BPB) in DMF. Compd. 1 constitutes a porous coordination framework that is built up by interconnecting 1-dimensional CoII polymer chains with (BPB)2- ligands. The thermal stability of 1 was studied by thermogravimetric (TG) anal. and variable-temp. X-ray powder diffraction (VTXRPD), which indicate that the framework of 1 is stable upon removal of solvent mols. The argon adsorption isotherm of 1 at 77 K indicates a porous structure with a BET surface area of 1207 m2/g. As a test reaction for catalytic activity of 1 the oxidn. of cyclohexene was examd. employing tert-Bu hydroperoxide as oxidant. The max. substrate conversion achieved after 12 h was 62% with an estd. turn-over no. (TON) of 44 based on the no. of converted substrate mols. (cyclohexene) per CoII atom.

      11h
      Structural, Magnetic, and Gas Adsorption Study of a Two-Dimensional Tetrazole-Pyrimidine Based Metal-Organic Framework
      Pachfule, Pradip; Das, Raja; Poddar, Pankaj; Banerjee, Rahul
      Crystal Growth & Design (2010), 10 (6), 2475-2478CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      A new two-dimensional (2D) metal-org. framework, Cu-TP-1 [Cu(TP)1.5(OH)], was synthesized under solvothermal conditions (DMF) from the transition metal cation Cu(II) and 2-tetrazol-5-ylpyrimidine (C5H5N6, H-TP). The structure was detd. by single crystal x-ray crystallog. which shows a (6,3) honeycomb 2D net with perpendicular one-dimensional channels. Permanent porosity of Cu-TP-1 was detd. by the nitrogen adsorption isotherm. Cu-TP-1 shows interesting H2 and CO2 uptake. CO2 uptake of Cu-TP-1 (at 298 K, 1 atm pressure) is comparable to the recently reported ZIF-95 which outperforms ZIF-100 and BPL carbon. The magnetic properties show an antiferromagnetically coupled Cu···Cu interaction down to 8 K with a Weiss temp. around 108 K.

      11i
      Synthesis and structural comparisons of five new fluorinated metal organic frameworks (F-MOFs)
      Pachfule, Pradip; Dey, Chandan; Panda, Tamas; Banerjee, Rahul
      CrystEngComm (2010), 12 (5), 1600-1609CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Fluorinated metal-org. frameworks (F-MOFs) were successfully synthesized under hydrothermal condition using 4,4'-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)bis(benzoic acid) (C17H10F6O4, H2hfbba) as a flexible dicarboxylate building block, Cu+2 and various heterocyclic co-ligands. These F-MOFs formulated as [Cu(hfbba)(phen)2]·2(H2hfbba)(H2O)(HCO2) (F-MOF-1), [Cu(hfbba)2(2,2'-bipy)2(H2O)] (F-MOF-2), [Cu(hfbba)(4,4'-dime-2,2'-bipy)(HCO2)]·(hfbba)(H2O) (F-MOF-3), [Cu2(hfbba)2(3-mepy)2]·(DMF)2(3-mepy) (F-MOF-4), and [Cu(hfbba)(phen)]·0.5(DMF) (F-MOF-5) (hfbba = 4,4'-(Hexafluoroisopropylidene)bis(benzoate), phen = 1,10-phenanthroline; 2,2'-bipy = 2,2'-bipyridine; 4,4'-dime-2,2'-bipy = 4,4'-dimethyl-2,2'-bipyridine; 3-mepy = 3-methyl-pyridine) display interesting H-bonded, 1-dimensional and 2-dimensional structural features. All these F-MOFs were structurally detd. by single-crystal x-ray diffraction. F-MOF-1 and 5 form a distorted octahedral Cu+2 secondary building unit (SBU). F-MOF-5 forms a 1-dimensional architecture constructed from Cu2+ ions bridged by phen anions and two types of 4 hfbba ligands while in F-MOF-1, two among the three acid co-ligands are not coordinated with Cu2+ ions. F-MOF-2 displays dinuclear SBUs within the three-dimensional frameworks whereas F-MOF-3 displays mononuclear SBUs and forms a 1-dimensional chain. F-MOF-4 display a interesting 2-dimensional framework with conventional Cu2(CO2)4 paddle wheel SBU. In the crystal structures four hfbba ligands, each coordinated to a dicopper paddle wheel unit via one of their carboxylate groups. Solid-state properties such as UV-visible and thermal stability of F-MOF-1-5 also were studied.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXpvVWgu74%253D&md5=4f1ffe66fe1c62df9a8e6a684ee8d310
    12. 12
      (a) Abrahams, B. F., Hawley, A., Haywood, M. G., Hudson, T. A., Robson, R., and Slizys, D. A. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2004, 126, 2894
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      12a
      Serendipity and Design in the Generation of New Coordination Polymers: An Extensive Series of Highly Symmetrical Guanidinium-Templated, Carbonate-Based Networks with the Sodalite Topology
      Abrahams, Brendan F.; Hawley, Adrian; Haywood, Marissa G.; Hudson, Timothy A.; Robson, Richard; Slizys, Damian A.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2004), 126 (9), 2894-2904CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The serendipitous discovery of a 3-dimensional [Cu(CO3)22-]n network with the topol. of the 4264 sodalite net in [Cu6(CO3)12(CH6N3)8]·K4·8H2O paved the way for the deliberate engineering of an extensive series of structurally related guanidinium-templated metal carbonates [M6(CO3)12(CH6N3)8]Na3[NMe4]·xH2O, where the divalent metal M in the framework may be Mg, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, or Cd. A closely related cryst. material with a [Ca(CO3)22-]n sodalite-like framework, but contg. K+ rather than Na+, [Ca6(CO3)12(CH6N3)8]K3[NMe4]·3H2O was also isolated. All of these compds. were obtained under the simplest possible conditions from aq. soln. at room temp., and their structures were detd. by single-crystal x-ray diffraction. Pairs of guanidinium cations are assocd. with the hexagonal windows of the sodalite cages, alkali-metal cations are assocd. with their square windows, and NMe4+ ions are located at their centers. Structures fall into two classes depending on the metal, MII, in the framework. One type, the BC type (Im‾3m), comprising the compds. for which M2+ = Ca2+, Mn2+, Cu2+, and Cd2+, has a bcc. unit cell, while the second type, the FC type (Fd‾3c), for which M2+ = Mg2+, Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+, and Zn2+, has a fcc. unit cell with edges on the order of twice those of the BC structural type. The metal M in the BC structures has four close carbonate oxygen donors and four other more distant ones, while M in the FC structures has an octahedral environment consisting of two bidentate chelating carbonate ligands and two cis monodentate carbonate ligands.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXhtVyqur4%253D&md5=b97c5ad485678f4a275044924f1e18de
      (b) Cheon, Y. E., Park, J., and Suh, M. P. Chem. Commun. 2009, 5436

      Selective gas adsorption in a magnesium-based metal-organic framework
      Cheon, Young Eun; Park, Jungeun; Suh, Myunghyun Paik
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2009), (36), 5436-5438CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A doubly interpenetrated magnesium-based porous metal-org. framework exhibits thermal stability up to 500° and selective gas sorption properties for H2 and O2 gases over N2, and CO2 gas over CH4.

      12c
      Framework materials assembled from magnesium carboxylate building units
      Davies, Robert P.; Less, Robert J.; Lickiss, Paul D.; White, Andrew J. P.
      Dalton Transactions (2007), (24), 2528-2535CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Four coordination polymers contg. Mg metal nodes and di- or tricarboxylic acid org. connectors were synthesized and structurally characterized with the aid of single crystal x-ray diffraction. Mg3(bdc)3(DMA)4 (1) and Mg3(bdc)3(EtOH)2 (2) were prepd. from the 1:1 reaction of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2bdc) with Mg(NO3)2·6H2O in dimethylacetamide (DMA) or EtOH, resp. Both 1 and 2 contain tri-metallic Mg carboxylate units which act as six-coordinate nodes for network construction. These tri-Mg nodes are joined by the bdc ligands in 1 to give a 2-dimensional layered structure with coordinated DMA solvent mols. between the layers, whereas in 2 they stack end-on to form a novel 3-dimensional network contg. 1-dimensional Mg carboxylate chains. Both 1 and 2 are moderately hygroscopic, and powder x-ray diffraction and TGA studies show them to be interconvertible with Mg(bdc) and the hydrated complex Mg(bdc)(H2O)2 via solid-state reactions. Reaction of Mg nitrate with 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid (H2bpdc) in DMA gives Mg3(bpdc)3(DMA)4 (3), which in contrast to 2 forms a squashed 3-dimensional cubic network as a result of the increased distance between the trinuclear nodes necessitated by the longer bpdc ligands. Reaction of Mg nitrate with the triangular org. building block 1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (H3btc) in DMA gives crystals of Mg(H1.5btc)2/3(btc)1/3(DMA)2·(DMA)1/3 (4). Compd. 4 contains mono-metallic metal nodes which assemble with the btc ligands to give 2-dimensional 63 tessellated layers with Mg-coordinated DMA mols. lying perpendicular to the layers. Some free DMA is also present in 4, sited in small pores between the layers.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXmtlGlu7o%253D&md5=9f2c54d8b085e9e8922edf0291567ad2
      (d) Dietzel, P. D. C., Blom, R., and Fjellvåg, H. Eur. J. Inorg. Chem. 2008, 2008, 3624

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      12e
      Hybrid Organic-Inorganic Framework Structures: Influence of Cation Size on Metal-Oxygen-Metal Connectivity in the Alkaline Earth Thiazolothiazoledicarboxylates
      Falcao, Eduardo H. L.; Naraso; Feller, Russell K.; Wu, Guang; Wudl, Fred; Cheetham, Anthony K.
      Inorganic Chemistry (2008), 47 (18), 8336-8342CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      We report the synthesis of four org.-inorg. frameworks of alk. earth cations with the org. ligand 2,5-thiazolo[5,4-d]thiazoledicarboxylate (C6N2S2O42-, Thz2-). Structures with remarkably different connectivities result when Mg2+, Ca2+, Sr2+, and Ba2+ react with Thz2-. Mg(Thz)(H2O)4 forms a 1-D coordination polymer in which one carboxylate oxygen on each terminus of the ligand connects individual MgO6 octahedra from their axial positions, while the remaining equatorial sites are coordinated by water mols. Ca2(Thz)2(H2O)8 forms a 1-D coordination polymer in which dimeric clusters with 7-fold Ca coordination are connected via the ligand in a linear fashion, with a second, uncoordinated Thz2- providing charge balance. Sr(Thz)(H2O)3 has 1-D infinite inorg. connectivity built from edge-sharing SrO7N polyhedra having one carboxylate oxygen and one water mol. acting as M-O-M bridges. Ba2(Thz)2(H2O)7 has 2-D inorg. connectivity based upon face- and edge-sharing BaO9N polyhedra. One carboxylate oxygen and all water mols. act as bridges between each Ba2+ and its three neighbors. We shall discuss the manner in which the increasing coordination requirements of the cations (MgO6 < CaO7 < SrO7N < BaO9N) lead to an increase in inorg. connectivity through the series.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtVSrtLjF&md5=90632650c8029033c65f53c53c845a76
      (f) Guo, Z., Li, G., Zhou, L., Su, S., Lei, Y., Dang, S., and Zhang, H. Inorg. Chem. 2009, 48, 8069
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      12f
      Magnesium-Based 3D Metal-Organic Framework Exhibiting Hydrogen-Sorption Hysteresis
      Guo, Zhiyong; Li, Guanghua; Zhou, Liang; Su, Shenqqun; Lei, Yongqian; Dang, Song; Zhang, Hongjie
      Inorganic Chemistry (2009), 48 (17), 8069-8071CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      A new magnesium metal-org. framework (MOF) based on an asym. ligand, biphenyl-3,4',5-tricarboxylate (H3BPT), was synthesized and structurally characterized. MOF Mg3(BPT)2(H2O)4 (1) consists of 1-dimensional hexagonal nanotube-like channels and exhibits pronounced hydrogen-sorption hysteresis at medium pressure.

      12g
      Temperature- and Stoichiometry-Controlled Dimensionality in a Magnesium 4,5-Imidazoledicarboxylate System with Strong Hydrophilic Pore Surfaces
      Gurunatha, K. L.; Uemura, Kazuhiro; Maji, Tapas Kumar
      Inorganic Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2008), 47 (15), 6578-6580CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      1D, 2-D, and 3-D three metal-org. hybrid frameworks of MgII were synthesized using 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (H3idc) with control of the temp. and stoichiometry in a hydrothermal technique. All of the frameworks, 1D {[Mg(Hidc)(H2O)2]·1.5H2O}n (1), 2D [Mg(Hidc)(H2O)]n (2), and 3D {[Mg3(idc)2(H2O)5]·2H2O}n (3), show high thermal stability, and dehydrated frameworks 1' and 3' provide highly hydrophilic pore surfaces, correlated by the selective sorption of H2O mols. over the org. vapor and other gases like N2 and CO2.

      12h
      Tetrakis(imidazolyl)borate-Based Coordination Polymers: Group II Network Solids, M[B(Im)4]2(H2O)2 (M = Mg, Ca, Sr)
      Hamilton, Barton H.; Kelly, Kathryn A.; Malasi, Wilhelm; Ziegler, Christopher J.
      Inorganic Chemistry (2003), 42 (9), 3067-3073CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      The authors are using the coordinating anion tetrakis(imidazolyl)borate to construct new metal-org. framework structures. The authors present three alk. earth metal network solids incorporating this anion. All three compds. have the same formula, M[B(Im)4]2(H2O)2 (M = Mg, Ca, Sr), and the same coordination environment about the metal. However, the three compds. have different network structures with different degrees of H bonding; the Mg material forms a two-dimensional network and the Ca and Sr compds. form 1-dimensional chains. The authors present the structure of the protonated anion B(HIm)(Im)3 as a model for the default structure of this anion and discuss how the conformation of tetrakis(imidazolyl)borate can affect the structure of network solids.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      12i
      Structural study of metal complexes of bisphosphonate amide ester: copper, magnesium, zinc and cadmium complexes of (dichloromethylene)bisphosphonic acid P-piperidinium-P'-methyl ester
      Jokiniemi, Jonna; Vuokila-Laine, Eija; Peraniemi, Sirpa; Vepsalainen, Jouko J.; Ahlgren, Markku
      CrystEngComm (2007), 9 (2), 158-164CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Four metal complexes of (dichloromethylene)bisphosphonic acid P-piperidinium-P'-Me ester were prepd. and their crystal structures detd. by x-ray single-crystal diffraction. The complexes were [{Cu3(CH3PO3CCl2PO2NC5H10)3(H2O)2}(H2O)3]2 (1), [(MgCH3PO3CCl2PO2NC5H10)(H2O)3]n (2), [{NaZn1.5(CH3PO3CCl2PO2NC5H10)2(H2O)2}(H2O)]n (3) and [{Cd(CH3PO3CCl2PO2NC5H10)(H2O)3}(H2O)]n (4). The Me ester of the piperidine deriv. of Cl2MBP (clodronate) forms with Cu the 1st wheel-like metal complex of bisphosphonate. The packing of this hexameric compd. 1 consists of channels occupied by aqua ligands and lattice H2O mols. Compds. 2-4 are polymers consisting of 1-dimensional chains of different compn.; in 3, coordinated Na+ cations hold the chains together, forming a 2-dimensional layered structure. Compds. 2 and 4 form layers through H bonds.
